txt.en: 'But it is no matter. It is passed, and I have my duty to my people to occupy me.'
You tell Éowyn that the coldness in her voice betrays her words.
'Would you not be cold, if you were made to sit idly instead of fighting the evils of the land?'
'You are a warrior and a traveller.'
'You think I am gloomy, then....'
'How could you understand the duties of a Lady of the House of Eorl?'
'Does it show upon my face, plain for all to see?'
'When you long to fight for your people, but instead you watch and wait while history happens around you.'
'Tell me, friend -- are you closely acquainted with the other travellers who departed with my uncle?'
You tell Éowyn that she hides it well, but it is there to see nonetheless.
You recount your many meetings with each guest, and her eyes light up when you speak of Aragorn.
'Well, there is no reason to be concerned for me.'
'Aragorn.'
'I admit that it was... difficult... to watch my uncle fade over the years.'
'The King of Gondor returned out of legend.... What do you know of him?'
'Wormtongue alone had his ear.'
'Poor decisions were made about the fate of Rohan.'
'And my brother, valiant Éomer, was imprisoned for his good deeds.'
'And Wormtongue watched my every step....'
Soldier
'Lady Éowyn!'
Signoth's Estate
'My lady!'
'What is it?'
'The watchtower-guards have spotted a warband near the city, heading south.'
'It will cut us off from Dunharrow!'
'Let me ride out with the city guards, my lady, and we will put an end to them.'
'No! I will go. Alone.'
'But... my lady!'
'Guard the gates, and flee to Dunharrow in case I do not return.'
